Posts.Content: I am scheduled for a needle biopsy on Monday, to examine two cysts identified in my left breast yesterday, on mammogram and ultrasound. My OB said there is no need for anesthesia and that it is uncomfortable but only lasts for a short time. I don't actually trust his pain assessment as he is not the one taking the tests. I would appreciate info from any lady who has gone through this procedure. I am definitely having the biopsy, I just want to be prepared for what is in store and need to know if I must have someone there with me or can I just go in alone? I don't have much of a support system, so I will need to make extra arrangements if I need to be accompanied. Thanks for any input you can offer!
Posts.Title: does a breast needle biopsy hurt?

Posts.Content: Thanks survivor 12! I was lucky and my biopsy report came back all clear. But the waiting was terrible! My heart goes out to all people going through similar things in their lives.
Posts.Title: does a breast needle biopsy hurt?

Posts.Content: Thanks for your post NMgal. I did have the biopsy last Monday and it was only a bit uncomfortable. They did use a lidocaine cream but in general the procedure was ok. I am currently waiting on my biopsy results and this is much harder than the actual biopsy. Mary
Posts.Title: does a breast needle biopsy hurt?

Posts.Content: My biopsy just came in and it is benign. No sign of cells that would mandate repeat tests or close follow up, just a benign lump. I am overjoyed and crying happy tears. I so hope that your tests come back as good as mine. You are in my thoughts and please update when you can! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: bookwriter, I am so sorry that the procedure was painful for you and also for the fact that the physician got you more worried than you originally were! I hope your results come back negative, still I think that your physician is right, even if it is benign, he wants it taken out and I can't see any harm in this other than the fact that you will have to undergo yet another procedure. It is common practice though, at least in my part of the world, to take out anything that might cause trouble in the future, even if it's not cancer. Even if this proves to be cancer, let's try and focus on the bright side that you would have caught it early and your physicians will plan the best treatment path for you. Please update when the results are in. You are in my thoughts! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: Trust me, you won't feel more than a slight sting when the needle comes in and by the time you get back home you won't even remember the procedure! If mine came back good, so can yours, so have hope and a positive outlook on things. Sending tons of good vibes your way bookwriter! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: Absolutely bookwriter! We will keep in touch and I hope we both do not have to talk about unpleasant stuff in the future. Before my biopsy I was freaking out afraid of the pain and everything, so if it's any comfort to you, the needle biopsy I had was no big deal and it only took like 10 minutes all together. I can tell you it's much harder waiting on the pathology report than the actual procedure itself. Do you know if they have scheduled you for a needle biopsy or a core biopsy? Hope everything goes well, I will be praying for a comfortable procedure and good biopsy results for you! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: Trust me, you won't feel more than a slight sting when the needle comes in and by the time you get back home you won't even remember the procedure! Please update when the results are in. You are in my thoughts! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: I had a biopsy last Monday and am currently hoping that my pathology report will be delivered by Friday. My ultrasound report sounds much similar to yours actually, without the armpit swelling. Although I am definitely worried, I am trying not to worry too much until I get my lab results. I have decided not to read and not to deal with statistics and chances as I am not sure these will ease my worries but increase them and I am not sure I can take that right now, so I can't really tell you anything about chances although I have people telling me all the time that lumps are benign most of the times. I totally understand how you feel and I am hoping that your procedure goes smoothly and the mass turns out to be benign. Best of luck, Mary

Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: I hit the post button too early. What I was trying to say is do go and get the tests, you are very young so it's probably nothing to worry about, but do have the tests please!
Posts.Title: Being sent for ultrasound and mammogram on Tuesday

Posts.Content: My biopsy just came in and it is benign. No sign of cells that would mandate repeat tests or close follow up, just a benign lump. I am overjoyed and crying happy tears. I so hope that your tests come back as good as mine. You are in my thoughts and please update when you can! Mary

Posts.Content: My biopsy just came in and it is benign. No sign of cells that would mandate repeat tests or close follow up, just a benign lump. I am overjoyed and crying happy tears. I so hope that your tests come back as good as mine. You are in my thoughts and please update when you can! Mary
Posts.Title: Having biospy Tuesday

Posts.Content: I just had a planned mammogram and ultrasound yesterday, the first one I ever had and only planned to have it because I am 42 and was supposed to have one. Ultrasound identified two masses in my left breast and returned me to the technician for some more mammogram images on the spot that only confirmed the finding. Today they called to schedule an appointment for a needle biopsy on Monday. I am trying not to get crazy with worry and hoping that if it's cancer, I caught it early enough to fight it off. It will be a long wait until I have the biopsy and then get the lab results, way too long.
Posts.Title: Being sent for ultrasound and mammogram on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Patti, I have been thinking about you. I am glad you had the onc appointment but I am sorry for what you are going through right now. I haven't been there so I cannot offer any real input but I understand it is a difficult choice to make. Still, since you do not have distant mets that would make things harder, surgery and then radiation and chemo, might deal with the problem and let you have a good life for many many years. Hair will grow back, so I wouldn't focus on that so much. Having your breast removed is a totally different thing and I can realize how that feels like a mutilation and a violation of your body, but if you have to choose between a breast and life... in my eyes life is more valuable than a breast. You and only you can make this decision, no one is in a position to make this decision for you. It's your body and your life and your peace of mind, so it's up to you to decide what's best for you! No matter what your decision is, we are here for you to help you through the next steps, whatever these may be. Big big hugs, Mary
Posts.Title: Anyone just not want to do it?

Posts.Content: Smiley1, I recently had two lumps identified through ultrasound and they had me take a needle biopsy, which fortunately came back all clear, but I am glad they wanted me to have it checked. I think you might consider getting a second opinion from a different physician, who will see your ultrasound report, feel the lump and suggest further tests if needed. Even it is benign (it sounds that's what your current doctor thinks), it is causing you pain, so there must be something they can do about it. Good luck! Mary
Posts.Title: Advice on armpit lymph node

Posts.Content: Just one more thing to add, Patti... chemo and radiation is not the same for everyone, some tolerate them well and others don't. My dad had chemo and radiation for his colon cancer 17 years ago and had absolutely no side effects and was cancer free for 17 years! For the lung cancer he is currently battling against, he has had various types of chemo, only one of which was bad for him and discontinued. You don't know how your body will react to treatment, it may be easier than what you are now thinking about. I think that is also something you might want to take into consideration in reaching a decision. More hugs, Mary
Posts.Title: Anyone just not want to do it?

Posts.Content: Hey Patti, I am so happy to hear from you. I am glad you are feeling better, I guess that after the hard process of making a decision, things start to seem a bit clearer... I too think that you have made a good decision and as Jody said, if it doesn't work or if you change your mind for whatever reason, you can always quit. I wish you the best of luck; I will be here for you every step of the way! (((Hugs))) Mary
Posts.Title: Anyone just not want to do it?
